algorithms.title: Chest Pain
algorithms.description: Evaluation of chest pain with focus on cardiac causes
mainComplaints: Pain radiating to neck, jaw, shoulders, back, or arms
Indigestion or heartburn with chest discomfort

cardiacCauses.name: Acute Coronary Syndromes (ACS)
cardiacCauses.description: Pain from myocardial hypoperfusion due to coronary artery occlusion

cardiacCauses.name: Unstable Angina (UA)
cardiacCauses.description: Rest pain for 20+ minutes, likely associated with unstable vessel occlusion

cardiacCauses.name: Variant Angina
cardiacCauses.description: Vasospastic angina with normal coronary arteries

cardiacCauses.name: Stable Angina
cardiacCauses.description: Chronic effort-dependent angina from imbalanced myocardial oxygen needs

history: Chief complaints indicating immediate cardiac care need
Past and current illnesses (diabetes, Marfan syndrome, anemia, lupus)
Severity, quality, location, duration, aggravating/relieving factors
Radiation of pain and associated symptoms
physicalExam: Inspect for signs of atherosclerosis (arcus senilis, arterial hardening)
Assess pulse at radial and femoral arteries
Assess for local tenderness, fractures, spinal diseases
Inspect feet for deep vein thrombosis
investigations: ECG - ST elevation/depression, Q waves, T wave changes
Echocardiogram - wall motion abnormalities, pericardial effusion
Chest X-ray - pneumonia, pneumothorax, lung pathology
preHospitalCare: Intravenous access, supplemental oxygen, pulse oximetry
referralIndications: Hypotension, poor tissue perfusion, pulmonary edema
patientEducation: Therapeutic lifestyle changes for cardiovascular risk
Reduced saturated fat, increased mono/polyunsaturated fats
Increased viscous fiber and plant stanols

algorithms.title: Dyspnea (Shortness of Breath)
algorithms.description: Evaluation of dyspnea with classification by duration and underlying cause

findings: Observe respiratory effort and accessory muscle use
Assess mental status and ability to speak
Check for pulsus paradoxus
Stridor indicates upper airway obstruction
Rectal temperature for fever detection
Neck vein distention suggests cor pulmonale or cardiac tamponade
Check thyroid for enlargement (congestive heart failure)
Ensure trachea is midline
Auscultate for stridor
Palpate for subcutaneous emphysema and crepitus
Percuss for dullness (consolidation or effusion)
Hyper-resonance suggests pneumothorax or emphysema
Auscultate for murmurs or extra heart sounds
Absent breath sounds may indicate pneumothorax or pleural effusion
Wheezing suggests obstructive lung disease or pulmonary edema
Rapid/irregular pulse may signify dysrhythmia
S3 gallop suggests LV systolic dysfunction
S4 gallop suggests LV dysfunction or ischemia
Loud P2 heard in pulmonary hypertension or cor pulmonale
Murmurs may indicate heart failure or dissection
Distant heart sounds suggest cardiac tamponade
Look for hepatomegaly and ascites
Hepatojugular reflux is valid for CHF diagnosis
Check for edema and signs of deep venous thrombosis
Examine digits for clubbing or cyanosis
Infiltrate characteristic of pneumonia
Vascular engorgement or pulmonary edema (CHF)
Hyperinflation (obstructive lung disease)
Pleural effusions or pneumothorax
Increased interstitial markings (interstitial lung disease)
Chest wall abnormalities or neoplastic lesion
Detects arrhythmia, ventricular hypertrophy, pericardial disease
Acute ST changes suggest angina or MI
Echocardiogram assesses systolic/diastolic dysfunction
Elevated WBC suggests infection (pneumonia)
Acute anemia may cause dyspnea
GERD with secondary bronchospasm should be considered in episodic symptoms

unstablePatients: Administer oxygen, ACLS guidelines, intubation if gasping
IV line access and fluid administration
Nebulized bronchodilator if obstructive disease present
IV or IM furosemide if pulmonary edema present
stablePatients: Obtain history to determine acuity level
Reassess airways, mental status, ability to speak, breathing effort
Check vital signs, focused history on medication, cough, fever, chest pain
Focused physical exam on breath sounds and skin color
furtherManagement: Smoking cessation for all COPD patients
Antibiotics for exacerbations with purulent sputum
Intensify inhaled treatment for symptomatic patients
Long-acting bronchodilators or combined therapy with short-acting beta2-agonist and anticholinergic

generalMeasures: Immunize against influenza and pneumococcal pneumonia
Control systolic and diastolic hypertension per guidelines
diuretics: Use in volume-overloaded patients for normal JVP and edema relief
IV or use 2 diuretics for diuretic resistance (furosemide + metolazone)
aceInhibitors: For all LV systolic heart failure or asymptomatic LV dysfunction
Contraindications: K+ >5.5, advanced renal failure (creatinine >3 mg/dL), bilateral renal artery stenosis, pregnancy
betaBlockers: For class II-III heart failure with ACE inhibitor and diuretics
Contraindications: Bronchospasm, symptomatic bradycardia, advanced heart block, unstable heart failure or class IV symptoms

referralGuidelines: Unstable patient after first aid treatment
Acute and rapidly progressive dyspnea to emergency room
When underlying cause cannot be established or symptoms disproportionate to severity
When specific diagnostic procedure needed (lung biopsy, cardiac catheterization)
Non-responders to therapy need subspecialty consultation
Suspected pulmonary disease may need pulmonary function testing
Arterial blood gas may be indicated for respiratory status
Spirometry distinguishes obstructive from restrictive lung disease
Pulse oximetry desaturation at rest or exercise indicates gas exchange abnormalities
